Dedicated to the 100th anniversary of Chemistry at Nankai University Single-atom catalysts for electrochemical energy storage and conversion Wei Ma Hao Wan Lili Zhang Jin You Zheng Zhen Zhou ⁎ Engineering Research Center of Advanced Functional Material Manufacturing of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China Engineering Research Center of Advanced Functional Material Manufacturing of Ministry of Education School of Chemical Engineering Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 Henan China Engineering Research Center of Advanced Functional Material Manufacturing of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review mainly focuses on major fabrication strategies of single atom catalysts for the electrocatalytic processes in different energy conversion and storage systems The expedited consumption of fossil fuels has triggered broad interest in the fabrication of novel catalysts for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Especially, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted more attention owing to their high specific surface areas and abundant active centers. This review summarizes recent synthetic strategies to fabricate SACs with different metal loadings on various supports, and the structural influence of supports on metal loading. Then, the functions of SACs are illustrated on electronic structure and electrocatalysis; the isolated SACs with an unsaturated coordination environment generally accelerate the electrocatalytic process and promote the selectivity. The applications of SACs to some typical electrocatalytic reactions are also introduced in detail, as well as to electrochemical energy storage and conversion systems. Finally, the challenges and the perspectives of SACs are discussed for future exploration. Keywords Single-atom catalysts Energy storage and conversion Electrocatalysis Batteries Fuel cells 1 Introduction The consumption of fossil fuels has triggered global warming and other serious environmental issues [1–3]. Especially, the extravagant utilization of fossil fuels makes it impossible to satisfy the ever-increasing energy demand for future daily life and industrial production [1,4]. Therefore, sustainable and clean electrochemical energy storage and conversion technologies have attracted more attention for the aim of carbon neutralization, and numerous efforts have been devoted to developing electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and so on [5–8]. Up to now, noble metals (such as Pt, Ir, and Ru) and transition metals (such as Fe, Co, and Ni) have been developed to fabricate efficient electrocatalysts [9–14]. Especially, noble metals present excellent electrocatalytic performances in some processes for electrochemical energy storage and conversion because of their unique electronic structure [15]. Nonetheless, the high cost and scarcity of noble metals prevent their large-scale practical applications [16]. Therefore, improving the utilization rate and electrocatalytic activity of noble metal-based electrocatalysts is a promising way towards efficient utilization and conversion of energy. Minimizing the usage of noble metals in electrocatalysts results in a low-coordination environment of metal centers, high surface-to-volume ratio, and quantum-size effects, which accordingly improves the electrocatalytic efficiency (Fig. 1 ) [17]. Recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs), the isolated metal atom singly anchored to the surface of the support, have been the new frontier in the catalytic field because of their high catalytic efficiency, resulting from the separated energy levels with the high occupied and low unoccupied molecular orbital [17–20]. The high atomic utilization of 100% in SACs favors the saving of metal catalysts, especially noble metals [20,21]. However, single-atom structures with high surface energy and chemical instability and isolated metal atoms tend to aggregate into clusters or nanoparticles [22,23]. Therefore, SACs always adopt low metal loading (about 0.1 wt%) to prevent aggregation, which leads to scant development in practical applications. Although the researchers realized the existence of the “unseen” metal active entities in 2003 because of the low metal loading [24], the direct observation of isolated metal atoms cannot be realized until the emergence of advanced characterization technologies, such as high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM). Specially, it is still a great challenge to fabricate SACs with massive loading [25–27]. To solve the problems, two promising strategies are proposed to stabilize and disperse single metal atoms: spatial confinement and coordination design [28–30]. The spatial confinement strategy is to construct hybrids of single metal atoms and carbon materials, resulting in a higher atomic utilization rate [28]. Especially, the spatial confinement strategy is suitable for fabricating SACs with high loading single metal atoms (about 5 wt%) by in situ decomposing porous polymeric precursors [31]. For the coordination design strategy, single atoms can be coordinated by neighboring heteroatoms with defects in the support, and the strong metal-support interaction creates the substantial metal loading in the support, i.e., metal oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, etc [32–36]. Therefore, the support with large surface areas and defects can provide massive sites to load single atoms with high catalytic activity and stability. Additionally, the strong metal-support interaction is an important factor to stabilize single atoms [37–39]. However, the excessively strong interaction between metal atoms and the support will decrease catalytic activity, while the weak interaction would affect the stability of single atoms. Therefore, optimal processes for synthesizing SACs should be further investigated to understand ideal binding sites for single atoms (SAs). Especially, the geometric and electronic structure of SAs and supports create unique charge transfer to modulate the adsorption of the intermediates, bringing superior efficiency and tunable selectivity to excellent electrocatalysts. To fabricate outstanding SACs, great efforts have been devoted and promising tactics are accessible to construct defects that are employed to anchor single atoms to generate stable and efficient SACs [40]. Especially, the unsaturated coordination environment for SACs enhances surface adsorption of intermediates, accelerating charge transport and facilitating activation processes [41]. Additionally, the heterogeneous interface of single metal atoms and the support with different electronegativities accelerates charge transfer, endowing SACs with excellent catalytic efficiency and selectivity [42]. Therefore, constructing the defects and modifying the coordination environment to stabilize metal single atoms with massive loading provides an effective pathway for the practical applications of single-atom electrocatalysts. Here, we comprehensively summarize the synthetic strategies for SACs in recent years and the explosive applications to electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Up to now, many reviews have emerged on SACs [43–45]; therefore, we focus on the latest progress and especially on typical electrocatalytic reactions and electrochemical energy storage and conversion systems. Finally, we demonstrate the trend and perspective for the future development of SACs in the electrocatalytic field. 2 Synthetic strategies for SACs The high surface energy of SACs causes the aggregation tendency of metal atoms in the support. Therefore, it is a great challenge to synthesize SACs. Up to now, various synthetic technologies have been approached to load single metal atoms in supports via the confinement or the coordination of metal atoms to the supports. SACs were achieved with different loadings of single metal atoms through numerous fabrication processes. 2.1 Coprecipitation methods Coprecipitation is a significant route to synthesize SACs, involving the simultaneous occurrence of the nucleation and growth process. Generally, SACs are approached by loading single metal atoms in hydroxides, oxides, and carbon materials through coprecipitation by regulating the interaction between single atoms and supports. In this process, the strong interface interaction and low metal loading in the support are necessary to limit aggregation. Zhang and co-workers synthesized the Pt1/FeO x SACs with the Pt loading of 0.17 wt% [19]. The Pt1/FeO x SACs were approached through the coprecipitation of H2PtCl6 and Fe(NO3)3 aqueous solutions under the pH of 8 at 50 °C. The special pH of the solution containing Pt and Fe facilitates the coprecipitation process. As shown in the HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 2 a), single Pt atoms occupy the positions of Fe atoms in the FeO x support. Further X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra indicate that the single Pt atoms hold positive charge, and it is different from the Pt foil and PtO2. In addition, the Pt-O bond length similar to that of PtO2 suggests the strong interaction between Pt and FeO x , which helps stabilize Pt single atoms and advances catalytic efficiency according to the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra. However, with increasing the Pt loading, Pt clusters formed on the FeO x surface. Compared with oxides, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) hold tunable chemical composition and large surface area, and are favorable to act as the support for SACs. Song et al. synthesized NiFe LDH monolayers supporting single-atom Ru catalysts (denoted as Ru1/mono-NiFe) via one-step coprecipitation. The structure analyses with XANES and EXAFS indicate that Ru atoms were anchored on top of Fe atoms via the coordination with three oxygen atoms around the Fe atoms (Fig. 2b and c). Detailed characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) computations verify that the unpaired electrons of Ru atoms on Fe atoms facilitate the electronic conduction and reduce the energy loss during the electrocatalytic process (Fig. 2d) [46]. Further study suggests that Pt1Au24 can be loaded on multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNs) to synthesize Pt SACs [47]. Although the coprecipitation technology has been employed to fabricate different SACs, the massive loading is still a great challenge due to the aggregation of SACs on the support. Meanwhile, the synthesis of SACs via coprecipitation technology was influenced by experimental parameters, such as reaction temperature and pH value. Therefore, it is urgent to develop novel strategies to fabricate SACs for mass production and practical applications. 2.2 Wetness impregnation technology For wetness impregnation technology, a precursor is exploited to fabricate catalysts by adsorbing dissolved metal ions on the support because of the capillary behavior and the successive drying process. Then the catalysts are further activated via calcination or reduction processes. This technology for synthesizing SACs has realized practical applications because of its technical simplicity, low cost, and high availability. However, the fabrication of isolated metal catalysts on the supports is inaccessible by using nitrates as the precursors for transition metals (such as cobalt, iron, and nickel) because of the redistribution during the drying process [48]. Adding the chelating citrate salts and viscosity increasing agents in the aqueous solution or leaching the supports to remove the metal element and enhancing the electrostatic adsorption provides the feasible approach to disperse the transition metals. Sun et al. synthesized single-atom Ru/CoFe LDH electrocatalysts by anchoring Ru on the CoFe LDH support with 0.45 wt.% Ru loading through the wetness impregnation technology (Fig. 3 a) because LDHs possess abundant active sites to anchor noble metal atoms [49,50]. In this electrocatalyst, LDH nanosheets were employed as the support for metal catalysts, and single Ru atoms are isolated on the CoFe LDH nanosheets, indicated by the spherical aberration-corrected STEM (AC STEM, Fig. 3b-d). The K-edge XANES in Fig. 3e suggests that the Ru K edge position of Ru/CoFe LDH is between RuO2 and metallic Ru. The Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectrum in Fig. 3f indicates the existence of only Ru-O and Ru-O-M (M = Co or Fe), suggesting that Ru was anchored on CoFe LDH. The model-based EXAFS fitting in Fig. 3g indicates that each Ru atom is coordinated with 3.9 ± 0.7 oxygen atoms; therefore, the isolated single Ru atoms are located on the surface of CoFe-LDH. Wu and his co-workers fabricated amorphous/crystalline FeCoNi LDHs, and the increased loading of 0.67 wt% was achieved because the amorphous structure on FeCoNi LDHs provided numerous defects and unsaturated coordination sites to anchor and stabilize single Ru atoms (Fig. 4 a) [51]. Hybridizing the amorphous/crystalline FeCoNi LDHs via the ion exchange process with a metal–organic framework (MOF), zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF)-67, is favorable to enhance the stability and activity of the hybrid. Ru atoms were stabilized on the surface of the amorphous/crystalline FeCoNi LDHs (AC FeCoNi LDHs) via the cation exchange process. The electrocatalyst still maintains the original hollow nanobox structure of ZIF-67 (Fig. 4b-d). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images in Fig. 4e-h and 3D atom-overlapping Gaussian-function fitting (AOGF) mappings in Fig. 4f, g, i, and j suggest that the amorphous layer uniformly covered the crystalline FeCoNi LDH. The lattice spacing of 0.261 nm is indexed to the plane of (012) in Fig. 4e and h. The aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM (AC HAADF-STEM) in Fig. 4k indicates that single Ru atoms are isolated on the amorphous/crystalline FeCoNi LDHs, which is further confirmed by 3D AOGF mapping in Fig. 4l, 3D isolines in Fig. 4m and intensity profile curve in Fig. 4n. The elemental mappings of Fe, Co, Ni, O, and Ru in Fig. 4o suggest that atomic Ru is homogeneously distributed over the entire AC FeCoNi LDHs. Each Ru atom is coordinated with four oxygen atoms. The active-site Ru can optimize the adsorption energy of intermediates and enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Besides, carbon-supported SACs were also exploited by impregnating sulfur-doped zeolite-templated carbon (HSC) into H2PtCl6 solution or phosphor-decorated g-C3N4 nanosheets (PCN) in RuCl3 solution to fabricate single Pt/HSC and Ru/PCN hybrids, ascribed to the heteroatom S and P anchoring single Pt and Ru atoms [52,53]. In addition, oxide-supported noble metal SACs, i.e., Pd1/TiO2 and Ru/ZnO, were also fabricated via the wetness impregnation technology and successive treatment [54,55]. The strong interaction between the SAs and the supports with different electronegativities induces the transfer of electrons and the spatial charge redistribution. 2.3 Low-temperature chemical reduction The chemical reduction method is a facile strategy to fabricate metal nanocrystals with different morphologies by controlling the nucleation and growth in liquid-phase reactions. The nucleation process firstly undergoes the formation of atomic or molecular species before forming nanocrystals. Single atoms are generally produced by reducing or decomposing the precursors. Recently, sub-nanometer clusters or single atoms have been generated by confining the chemical reduction into a nanoscale space and affecting the nucleation of materials. Controlling the nucleation and crystal growth provides a promising way to synthesizing nanocrystals and single atoms through conventional photochemical reductions and by freezing the precursor solution for photochemical reactions (Fig. 5 a). Wu et al. synthesized Pt nanocrystals (Fig. 5b) and single atoms in amorphous carbon films (Fig. 5c), mesoporous carbon (Fig. 5d), graphene (Fig. 5e), MWCNTs (Fig. 5f), TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 5g) and ZnO nanowires (Fig. 5h) via iced-photochemical reduction with ultraviolet (UV) irradiation of frozen chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6) aqueous solution because of the reduction performance of UV. The H2PtCl6 aqueous solution was frozen to yield the ice with a homogeneous concentration of Pt(IV) with the cooling rate of 40 °C min−1, and then photochemical reduction of Pt(IV) proceeded at the temperature of −25 °C for 1 h [56]. Hybridizing the aqueous solution with various supports, and washing and drying the samples several times, single Pt atoms were stabilized in the supports. Iced-photochemical reduction leads to high-density areas of isolated Pt atoms in the supports and no clusters and nanoparticles were observed, indicating the promising synthesis tactics for noble metal single atoms. With a similar method, Ag (Fig. 5i) and Au (Fig. 5j) single atoms were generated on ultrathin carbon films. In addition, the iced-photochemical reduction method was further expanded to the ice‐melting reduction with NaBH4 as the reductant. The precursor containing AgNO3 was frozen into ice and submerged into the NaBH4 aqueous solution under the temperature of ~ 0 °C. The ice-containing AgNO3 melted slowly and released AgNO3 into the NaBH4 aqueous solution. The atomically dispersed Ag was synthesized because of the suppressed nucleus formation. Further results indicate that the atomically dispersed Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Os, Ir, Pt, and Au were accessible, suggesting that the ice-melting process can efficiently prevent the nucleation and growth of metal atoms. 2.4 Atomic‐layer deposition Atomic-layer deposition (ALD) has been the focus as a deposition method for ultra-thin films because of its unique uniform deposition and conformal films with controllable composition and thickness on complex surfaces [57,58]. The ALD process includes exposure to the first precursor, a purge of the reaction chamber, exposure to the second reactant precursor, and the further purge of the reaction chamber (Fig. 6 a) [59]. Especially, the self-limiting reactions in the ALD process make it possible to preciously control the size and thickness of the deposited materials at the atomic scale. For the reaction of steps 1 and 2, the precursor reacts with the active sites on the support, and a fraction of the ligands of the precursor are partially removed. The residues of the precursor and the byproducts are cleaned by the gas. For steps 3 and 4 of the ALD process, the reactant precursor reacts with the adsorbed precursor in steps 1 and 2 to get the resulting products by removing the remaining ligands of the first precursor. In this process, regenerating active sites on the surface of the deposited products is vital for the next cycle deposition. The residues of the second precursor and byproducts are further cleaned by the inert gas and the reaction cycle is completed. In this ALD process, it is accessible to achieve the control of the size and thickness by adjusting the cycle number [60]. Therefore, depositing single atoms on the supports is achieved by controlling the ALD cycle. Sun and his co-workers synthesized Pt single atoms on graphene nanosheets with carbon vacancies and defects with the ALD method because the vacancies and defects facilitate anchoring Pt precursors [61]. In addition, the morphology, size, and Pt loading on graphene can be controlled by the number of the ALD cycle (Fig. 6b). Up to now, various supports, such as TiO2, CeO2, and nitrogen-doped graphene, have been employed to fabricate SACs [55,62–64]. For example, Zheng and coworkers synthesized stable atomically dispersed palladium-titanium oxide catalysts (Pd1/TiO2) with the Pt loading of 1.5 wt%. In this process, ethylene glycolate was used to stabilize Pt atoms on TiO2 [55]. Lu et al. used oxygen functional groups on graphene to anchor palladium hexafluoroacetylacetate (Pd(hfac)2) to synthesize single-atom Pd catalysts via ALD. The anchoring sites react with Pd(hfac)2 and stabilize Pd atoms after the removal of hfac ligands (Fig. 6c) [64]. Numerous noble SACs have been synthesized with ALD. Besides, ALD has been employed to fabricate transition metal SACs. Liang and coworkers fabricated Fe SACs on SiO2 and TiO2 via ALD. Fe was deposited on the degassed SiO2 and TiO2 supports with ferrocene and hydrogen as precursors in a fluidized bed reactor with the reaction temperature of 400 °C, and the ligand was finally removed with the flush N2 gas as shown in Fig. 6d [65]. Therefore, the suitable ligands and the anchored sites make it accessible to fabricate SACs. 2.5 High-temperature pyrolysis High-temperature pyrolysis is a promising strategy to synthesize SACs via the pyrolysis of selected precursors at appropriate pyrolysis temperature, i.e., 600–1000 °C [66–68]. According to different precursors, the pyrolysis method can be divided into two classes, pyrolysis of specific metal-containing complexes (mainly including MOF-based precursors), and pyrolysis of irregular metal-containing complexes, metal-containing organic polymers, and a mixture of metal and carbon sources. According to different precursors, different pyrolysis temperatures are necessary to synthesize SACs. MOFs, especially ZIFs, which hold unique morphology and N-containing organic linkers, are widely used as self-templates to fabricate porous carbon catalysts containing N-coordinated metal sites, high porosity and large surface area. The highly-dispersed metal and N atoms improved the electrocatalytic efficiency. Jiang et al. synthesized single-atom iron-implanted N-doped porous carbon (FeSA-N-C) with a high content of 1.76 wt % via the pyrolysis of PCN‐222 (a kind of MOFs) [69]. The fabrication procedure is presented in Fig. 7 a. Li group further developed the pyrolysis method to synthesize Co SACs with the metal loading over 4 wt% via pyrolysis of bimetallic Zn/Co MOFs (Fig. 7b) [66]. In this process, Zn was employed to expand the adjacent distance of Co atoms and evaporated at high temperatures over 800 °C, endowing the possibility to generalize this strategy to other metals, such as Fe, Ni, Mn, Ir and Cr [69–73]. However, for this pyrolysis process, it is necessary to employ the well-defined graphene matrix or precursors such as polymers or MOFs with high surface area and heteroatoms to anchor metal single atoms. The pre-designed MOFs and poisonous etching processes make it sophisticated to fabricate SACs. Therefore, Wang et al. further developed the pyrolysis method to synthesize SACs by using the commercial carbon black with active surface. The unique active sites in the surface of carbon black were employed to trap Ni single atoms with the aid of urea at 800 °C in the Ar atmosphere (Fig. 7c) [74]. Excitingly, Li and his co-workers have recently synthesized gram-scale SACs with high loading, and the contents of different metal elements are as high as 21.57 wt% (Ni), 22.36 wt% (Cu), 21.09 wt% (Zn), and 13.47 wt% (Ru). In addition, the noble metal loadings of SAC-Rh (3.5 wt%), SAC-Pd (3.8 wt%), SAC-Pt (3.2 wt%) and SAC-Ir (4.4 wt%) are also at a high level [75]. Therefore, this strategy provides a promising pathway for gram-scale SACs. According to the above-mentioned fabrication processes, isolated metal atoms are always anchored to the supports via the confinement and the coordination strategies to prevent the aggregation tendency of metal atoms, and massive defective sites or heteroatoms in the supports are necessary to stabilize metal atoms. Therefore, the high- superficial supports with massive defects and heteroatoms provide an accessible pathway to fabricating SACs with high metal loading. In addition, the comparison of advantages and disadvantages of various fabrication strategies are summarized in Table 1 to further understand different synthesis strategies. Especially, the high-temperature pyrolysis of organic compounds, especially for MOFs, is the most promising strategy to fabricate SACs with massive metal loading. Additionally, because of the invisible size of SACs, advanced characterization technologies were employed to identify the single-atom structure. Scanning tunneling microscope (STM) and HAADF-STEM are usually utilized to characterize the morphology, structure and atomic distribution. The chemical state, coordination environment and the configuration of SACs are explored with XAFS and XANES [76]. By combing with HAADF-STEM or STM, in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of CO adsorption was used to further confirm SACs with the specific vibration bands of chemisorbed CO with the catalysts [77]. In addition, the Raman technologies (i.e., surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy) are also employed to investigate the structure information of SACs [78]. 3 Applications of SACs to typical electrocatalytic reactions Recently, SACs have been applied to various electrocatalytic processes because of their outstanding catalytic efficiency and inimitable selectivity. Up to now, various novel SACs have been synthesized, and the designed electrocatalysts hold the excellent electrocatalytic performances with low overpotential and high faradaic efficiency (FE) in the basic or acid media for different electrocatalytic processes (Table 2 ). In the following section, we will discuss typical electrochemical reactions with SACs as the electrocatalysts, documenting the great capability and potential of SACs in the field of electrochemical energy conversion. 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) Hydrogen (H2), as a zero-emission carbon-free fuel, possesses an energy density of 33.3 kW h kg−1 [90], and is regarded as the most promising energy carrier. Overall water splitting (H2O → H2 + 1/2O2) provides a clean, efficient, and sustainable hydrogen production technology with promising prospects. While the large-scale commercial application of electrolytic H2 production technology still has limitations in terms of high cost and poor performance of electrocatalysts. For the multistep hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the first step is called Volmer reaction (H + * + e → H*), and, the following step has two different pathways, Heyrovsky reaction: H + e + H* → H2 + *, or Tafel reaction: 2H* → H2 + *, where * designates an active site on the surface of the electrode [91]. Pt-based nanomaterials supported on carbon black exhibit high exchange current density, which is the preferred catalyst for HER. Considering the high cost and scarcity of Pt, tremendous investigations have been devoted to exploring cost-effective alternative catalysts. Cheng et al. investigated the effect of downsizing Pt nanoparticles for HER. To highly maximize the efficiency and utilization of Pt atoms, they synthesized isolated single Pt atoms and clusters anchored on nitrogen-doped graphene nanosheets by ALD. The Pt SACs exhibited significantly enhanced HER mass activity (10.1 A mgPt−1), which is 37.4 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C catalyst (0.27 A mgPt−1) [92]. Fang and co-workers also synthesized Pt SACs supported on MOF-derived N-C frameworks (Pt1/N-C) via ALD, with ~ 2.5 wt% Pt content in Pt1/N-C [93]. The nature of the single-atom Pt site under electrocatalytic HER conditions was observed by operando XAFS measurements. The results revealed that the single Pt atom is closer to zero valence and its geometric structure makes the less coordination number to the support; therefore, single Pt atoms tended to escape from the N-C support dynamically during the electrocatalysis, resulting in high HER activity in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M NaOH solution. Additionally, EXAFS spectra of the samples exhibited strong consistency before and after reactions, demonstrating that the evolution of Pt sites is well reversible. Affected by the activation of water molecules, the HER activity of Pt-based materials in alkaline media is inferior to that in acidic ones [94]. Surprisingly, some Pt-free catalysts display excellent HER performance in alkaline electrolytes, resulting from the high activation ability for H2O and weak adsorption of H* and OH*. Especially, the facile dissociation of H2O contributes to faster proton supply, which is beneficial to overcome the efficiency loss in the Volmer reaction. Tan group designed single-atom Ru supported on nano-porous MoS2 (Ru/np-MoS2) (Fig. 8 a) [95]. The Ru/np-MoS2 catalyst exhibited high activity for alkaline HER (Fig. 8b and c). DFT computations and spectral characterizations indicate that the bending strain of the Ru/np-MoS2 catalyst effectively regulates the electronic structure of single Ru atoms, catalyzing the dissociation of H2O and coupling of H-H more effectively. Transition metal based SACs also show remarkable HER performance. Chen et al. designed Mo-based SACs for HER, in which single Mo atoms are anchored with one nitrogen atom and two carbon atoms (Mo1N1C2) [96]. The Mo1N1C2 catalyst with a 3D porous structure has a specific surface area of 583 m2/g and displays outstanding HER performance, with a low onset potential and negligible activity degradation after 1000 cycles in alkaline solutions. Cao and co-workers prepared single-atom Co supported on phosphorized carbon nitride (Co1/PCN), which forms a structurally uniform Co1-N4 moiety [97]. The turnover frequency (TOF) of Co1/PCN was 0.22 and 5.98 H2 s−1 at overpotentials of 50 and 100 mV, respectively, which are higher than that of commercial Pt/C. The Tafel slope of Co1/PCN is 52 mV dec−1, suggesting the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism for HER. Moreover, Co1/PCN shows higher electrocatalytic activity than Co1/CN due to the improved electrical conductivity by P doping. Operando XAFS on uniform single-atom Co revealed the formation of HO-Co1-N2 moiety resulting from the binding between Co1-N4 sites with the alkaline electrolyte, which promotes the activation of H2O. The interaction between single atoms and the support is the direct factor in the electrocatalytic performance [98,99]. Qi et al. found that the phase of MoS2 transforms from 2H to distorted 1 T (D-1 T) due to lattice mismatch and formation of Co-S bonding between single atom Co and MoS2 [98]. The atomic cobalt array covalently bound to D-1 T MoS2 nanosheets (SA Co-D 1 T MoS2) (Fig. 8d) achieves a TOF of 7.82 H2 s−1 at an overpotential of 100 mV and a Tafel slope of 32 mV dec−1 (Fig. 8e and f), which is Pt-like activity towards HER. Different from the Pt1/N-C catalyst that forms the near-free Pt SA under the electrocatalytic process [76], the formation of HO-Co1-N2 moiety is affected by the electrolyte under the open circuit potential [79], and the SA Co-D 1 T MoS2 catalyst requires electrochemical pretreatment to form active sites [80]. The former forms a reversible dynamic catalytic active center; however, the latter two reflect the effect of the electrolyte or electrochemical pretreatment on the active center of the catalyst, providing new strategies for the preparation of highly active SACs. As mentioned above, HER requires low-cost catalysts with high activity, long-term stability, and electrolytes with a wide pH range. SACs show certain application prospect, and increasing the metal loading will lead to a high H2 yield rate at low overpotentials. Although numerous efforts have been devoted, further exploring the universal techniques for efficiently loading single metal atoms is critical to the prospects for the commercialization of electrolytic hydrogen production. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) Oxygen evolution reaction (OER), as the anodic reaction of water splitting, is a kinetically sluggish process. Compared with the fast HER, the slow four-electron transfer process of OER is the limiting factor on the overall performance of the electrolytic system [100–102]. Generally, the OER process involves the breaking of O–H bonds and the formation of O-O bonds, resulting in a series of intermediates, including OH*, O*, and OOH*. According to Sabatier’s principle, the adsorbates must be properly bound to the catalyst surface to achieve high activity, neither too strong nor too weak. The calculated adsorption of oxygen species is usually used as the descriptor to predict and understand the OER activity of electrocatalysts [103,104]. Over the years, tremendous OER catalysts have been designed to get the appropriate adsorption energy and excellent OER performance [105–109]. Among them, SACs have attracted wide attention because of their unique morphology and electronic properties. In general, Ru- and Ir-based nanomaterials are the best electrocatalysts for OER. To reduce the metal loading and save the cost, it is a feasible strategy to downsize the nanoparticles to single atoms. Zhang and co-workers incorporated single Ir atoms into defect-rich cobalt hydroxides (Co(OH)2) to enhance the OER activity [110]. The dispersed single-atom Ir provided rich unsaturated sites for the formation of Co-Ir species. Although Ir species were electro-oxidized to a higher valence state during the catalytic process, the atomic dispersion was still maintained. Moreover, α-Co(OH)2 was electro-oxidized to CoOOH during the electrochemical process, which provides a suitable adsorption state for intermediate species, accelerating the OER process. As a result, CoIr-0.2 exhibited a higher OER activity than IrO2 in both 1.0 M KOH electrolyte and 1.0 M phosphoric buffer solution. Wang et al. incorporated atomic Ir or Ru into NiV layered double hydroxide (LDH) with a one-pot hydrothermal method [111]. There are synergistic interactions among Ni, V, and Ir (or Ru) atoms. Specifically, the introduction of Ir accelerates the breaking of O–H bonds, while doping accelerates the formations of O-O bonds. Compared with NiV-LDH, the OER performances of both NiVIr-LDH and NiVRu-LDH were enhanced. Sun group further investigated the synergistic effect between Ru and a series of binary LDHs [49]. Transition metals (M = Fe, Co, Ni) provide electrons to Ru through Ru-O-M bonds, reducing the valence of Ru and creating coupling effects. Further, binary LDHs with smaller electronegativity (such as CoFe) provide stronger electronic coupling, while metal ions without d electrons (such as Mg2+ and Al3+) hardly have coupling effects. The experiments demonstrate that the coupling effects improve the OER activity and reduce the dissolution of Ru. Lou group reported atomically Ni anchored on an N-doped hollow carbon matrix (HCM@Ni-N) as an electrocatalyst for OER in an alkaline medium (Fig. 9 a-f) [112]. EXAFS and XANES revealed that the isolated Ni centers adopt an unsaturated coordination geometry with Ni-N bonding in HCM@Ni-N. The calculated distribution of charge density revealed that the Ni-N bonding greatly modifies the 3d orbital distribution of Ni in HCM@Ni-N, improving the charge polarization of Ni sites. This weakens the interaction between HCM@Ni-N and intermediates, and promotes the OER kinetics. The electrochemical measurements displayed that HCM@Ni-N possesses a Tafel slope of 76 mV dec−1, which is smaller than those for HCM@Ni (187 mV dec−1) and HCM@N (203 mV dec−1). Additionally, the HCM@Ni-N catalysts exhibited long-term durability; the current density remained stable over 12 h with almost negligible degradation at a fixed potential, and only about a 1.2% increase in the required potential at the current density of 20 mA cm−2 for 12 h. In recent years, abundant designed electrocatalysts have focused on improving the activity of OER catalysts. The stability of SACs at high potential is still the major hurdle for the application to OER, especially the oxidation and dissolution of transition metals in acidic solutions. In this aspect, diluted surface alloys may represent a more promising system than coordinated single atoms. 3.3 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The global fossil fuel shortage and the resulting problems such as environmental pollution and climate change urgently require renewable and clean energy technologies. Fuel cells are energy storage and conversion devices that convert the chemical energy of fuels into electrical energy. The required fuels (such as H2, NH3, CH3OH and CHOOH) could be produced by electrosynthesis technology powered by renewable energy sources [113,114]. Therefore, fuel cells are potential clean energy conversion devices. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is the cornerstone for fuel cells and other renewable energy conversion and storage devices, such as metal-air batteries [115]. However, the performance and lifetime of fuel cells are significantly limited by ORR due to the following two major obstacles. The sluggish kinetics of ORR results in an approximately 10 times larger overpotential than that of hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) [116]. Therefore, ORR electrocatalysts with high activity and low Pt content are required to improve the performance and reduce the cost. Over the past a few decades, some effective strategies and methods have been selected to construct various morphologies and compositions of Pt-based catalysts to expose more Pt surfaces and active sites, such as Pt nanowires, alloys, and core–shell structures, effectively improving the specific activity for ORR [117–122]. Recent studies have tended to design and synthesize Pt-based SACs and non-platinum catalysts to further reduce the loading of Pt in ORR catalysts. Compared with alloy and core–shell structures, SACs have a larger specific surface area and can maximize the use of active sites of metal atoms. Additionally, metal single atoms have more unsaturated active sites, which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of O2, further improving the ORR performance [123,124]. Liu et al. designed N-doped carbon-supported Pt SACs (denoted as Pt1-N/BP) for ORR [125]. Pt1-N/BP contains only single Pt atoms, while there were small Pt x clusters or nanoparticles in Pt1/BP, indicating that N doping could effectively prevent the aggregation of Pt single atoms and improve the dispersion of Pt single atoms. Pt1-N/BP possesses better ORR activity and long-term operation stability than Pt1/BP in both acidic and alkaline conditions (Fig. 10 a). Additionally, the Pt1-N/BP catalyst showed excellent tolerance to poisoning, and the current of the fuel cell with Pt1-N/BP remains 90% after working for 200 h continuously at 70 °C. DFT computations and experimental characterizations revealed that the main active sites are single-pyridinic-nitrogen-atom-anchored single-platinum-atom centers, and the excellent performance of Pt1-N/BP is attributed to the synergistic effect of N doping to Pt single atoms. Similarly, Liu and co-workers also reported that carbon-defect-anchored (defective Black Pearls 2000, denoted as BPdefect) Pt SAC (Pt1/BPdefect) exhibited high ORR activity and long-term durability (Fig. 10b) [126]. Further characterizations and DFT computations indicated that Pt single atoms anchored by four carbon atoms in divacancy graphene (Pt-C4 site, g-2-Pt) are the main active sites for ORR. An acidic H2/O2 single cell with Pt1/BPdefect as the ORR electrode delivered a maximum power density of 520 mW cm−2 at 80 °C, delivering super-high Pt utilization of 0.09 gPt kW−1. In recent years, transition metal-based SACs, especially isolated single metal-N x (M−N x ) modified carbon or transition metal and nitrogen co-doped carbon (M−N−C) materials have attracted extensive attention and served as the most promising alternative to Pt-based catalysts for ORR. Zhang et al. synthesized a single Fe atom-based Fe-N-C catalyst and achieved a low overpotential for ORR, only 30 mV higher than that of commercial Pt/C [127]. Although Fe-based SACs have considerable ORR performance, its activity loss caused by free radical coupling electro-Fenton reactions is yet not to be addressed [128]. To develop Pt-free and Fe-free catalysts for low-cost and durable fuel cells, Yin et al. synthesized a stable Co-based SAC by pyrolysis of Zn/Co bimetallic MOFs [66]. The obtained catalyst with Co-N x single sites showed excellent ORR performance, with an E 1/2 of 0.881 Vvs. RHE (RHE: reversible hydrogen electrode) and high durability in alkaline media. Xie and co-workers also prepared Co-N-C catalysts with high content of atomic Co-N x sites with a high current density of 0.22 A cm−2 at 0.9 ViR-free for ORR [129]. Some recent studies have also pointed out that the large electronegativity of the symmetric adjacent N atoms around the transition metal (M) site in M−N4 moiety may lead to inappropriate free energies for adsorbed intermediates, which seriously reduces the kinetic activity and affects the ORR performance [130]. Adjusting the interface configuration of M atoms can change the adsorption strength of ORR intermediates at central active sites, which results in a low potential barrier and high ORR activity [131]. Shang and co-workers designed single Cu atoms bonded with both sulfur and nitrogen atoms in hierarchically porous carbon derived from MOFs (denoted as S-Cu-ISA/SNC) (Fig. 10c) [132]. There was unsymmetrical Cu-S1N3 atomic moiety in the carbon matrix, and the low-valent Cu(+1) species worked as active centers for ORR. The S-Cu-ISA/SNC catalyst with Cu-S1N3 moiety exhibited excellent ORR activity with an E 1/2 of 0.918 V (vs. RHE) in an alkaline electrolyte (Fig. 10d). This discovery provides a universal strategy for controllable synthesis of other metal-based SACs, such as Mn, Fe, Co and Ni SACs. According to the above discussion, Pt-based SACs and Pt-free catalysts represent promising choices. However, the active centers mentioned above still suffer from either low selectivity or poor durability. Especially for Pt-based SACs, many studies have shown that ORR is more likely to generate hydrogen peroxide by a two-electron transfer reduction pathway at the isolated Pt active sites [52,133–136]. Fe-N-C, as the most active moieties in Pt-free catalysts, have poor durability because of free radical coupling electro-Fenton reactions, which were derived from the decomposition of H2O2 byproduct in ORR. To tackle these challenges, further exploration and strategies are urgently needed for the design, characterization, and mechanistic research of SACs. 3.4 Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) Ammonia (NH3), a raw material for fertilizer and chemical manufacture, is also a carbon-free fuel [137–139]. NH3 possesses a high gravimetric hydrogen content of 17.6 wt% and an energy density of 5.52 kW h kg−1. NH3 can be stored as a liquid at a pressure of 9–10 bar at ambient temperature, making it safer than H2. Moreover, the established railway, highway, ship, pipeline, and other reliable infrastructures can be used for the safe transport of NH3. The advantages of NH3 in the energy economy have attracted extensive attention [140–142]. However, the industrial production of NH3 currently relies on the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process under high temperature and pressure (350–550 °C, 15–30 MPa), which consumes high coal-based energy input and generates ~ 1% of the annual global CO2 emissions [143,144]. Therefore, a sustainable NH3 preparation process with mild and environment-friendly conditions is urgently needed. The electrochemical ammonia synthesis by nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR, N2(g) + 6H2O(l) + 6e- → 2NH3(aq.) + 6OH-(aq.), E 0 = 0.092 V vs RHE) under ambient conditions is an electrically driven process of CO2-free energy conversion, which has a great potential for sustainable development [145]. Although experimental studies have been reported since the 1960 s, the FE of NH3 synthesis is lower than 1% due to the high bond energy of the N≡N triple bond (941 kJ mol−1) and the competitive HER (E 0 = 0 V vs RHE) [146–148]. High-performance catalysts with sufficient activity and selectivity are important to improve the efficiency of electrochemical ammonia synthesis. SACs have unique N2 adsorption and activation characteristics. Specifically, the metal center of SACs possesses abundant unsaturated active sites, which substantially strengthen N2 adsorption. The diverse properties of supports could synergistically increase the efficiency of nitrogen fixation. These exciting features of SACs make it very attractive for NRR. For example, Geng et al. designed Ru single atoms on N-doped carbon (Ru SA/N-C) by pyrolyzing Ru-containing ZIF-8, and the barrier for the hydrogenation of *N2 to *NNH on Ru-N3 moiety is much lower than that on Ru(101) surface [149]. Synergistic with the porous carbon skeleton to promote the dispersion and adsorption of N2 molecules, Ru SA/N-C exhibits excellent NRR performance, with the FE and NH3 yield up to 29.6% and 120.9 μg·mgcat. −1h−1 at −0.2 V vs. RHE, respectively (Fig. 11 a and b). Another Ru-based SAC supported on ZrO2/N-C also showed a high NH3 yield of 3.665 mg·mgRu −1h−1 at −0.21 Vvs. RHE and an NH3 FE of 21% at a low overpotential of 0.17 V [150]. In addition to dispersing single atoms on porous carbon, the electronic effect between single atoms and two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets can also significantly improve the NRR performance. 2D nanosheets have a large specific surface, high conductivity, and adjustable active sites, favoring ion adsorption and electron transport [151]. Wang et al. synthesized well-dispersed Au SAs on carbon nitride (Au1/C3N4) [152], and the prepared Au1/C3N4 displayed the highest FE of 11.1% at −0.1 Vvs. RHE in acidic media (Fig. 11c and d). In contrast, the Au NP/C3N4 catalyst only achieved an FE of 6% under the same condition. The NH3 yield of Au1/C3N4 was up to 1.305 mg·mgAu −1h−1, which was about 22.5 times higher than that of Au NP/C3N4. DFT computations revealed that NRR on Au1/C3N4 needs to overcome a lower barrier than that on Au(211). The better NRR performance of Au1/C3N4 results from the stronger interaction with *NNH. Specifically, the Bader charge analysis shows that there is significant charge transfer from Au1 to g-C3N4, which may shift the d-orbital position of Au1 towards the Fermi level and then enhance its binding with *NNH, and improve the NRR activity. Compared with noble metal-based SACs, non-noble metal-based SACs have the advantages of abundant reserve and low price, and generally have poor HER activity, which is conducive to NRR. In particular, Mo- and Fe-based catalysts have attracted wide attention because of their important roles in biological nitrogen fixation, and Fe is one of the earliest metals used in NRR [153]. Sclafani et al. observed that the maximum FE for NRR on metallic Fe was only around 1%, resulting from the sluggish NRR kinetics [154]. Comparatively, in a recent study by Wang group, the FeSA-N-C catalysts exhibit an excellent FE of 56.55% at 0 Vvs. RHE in 0.1 M KOH [86]. DFT computations indicated that the high energy barrier for water splitting hinders the adsorption of *H on FeSA-N-C surface, preferentially favoring the NRR pathways during electrocatalysis. Zhang and co-workers designed a protrusion-like Fe-based SAC anchored on MoS2 (SACs- MoS2-Fe) (Fig. 11e-h) [155]. The protrusion-like Fe single atoms anchored on MoS2 nanosheets triggered the electrical and interfacial polarization fields, which drive more electrons to donate to N2 antibonding orbitals at a faster rate and promote N2 activation. As a result, a superior NH3-evolving rate of 36.1 ± 3.6 mmol g−1h−1 was achieved on the SAC-MoS2-Fe catalyst in an electrochemical flow cell. The origin of the polarization between heterojunction interfaces was studied by ab initio molecular dynamics simulations, which was confirmed in experiments from the function relationship between N2-budding time and surface potential difference (△E, △E = E N2-E Ar). Similar phenomena of polarization results were also observed for other metal SACs supported on MoS2 nanosheets, such as Co-MoS2 and Cu-MoS2. However, some catalysts prepared for comparison, consisting of Au/Bi-metal and C3N4/N-doped carbon support, showed at least 7 times lower NRR activity than the SAC-MoS2-Fe catalyst under the same operating parameters. As mentioned above, the application of SACs in NRR has significantly improved the efficiency of electrochemical nitrogen fixation. However, the NH3 yield rate in electrocatalytic NRR remains extremely low, hindering the commercial application of such a sustainable technology. Future research of SACs for nitrogen fixation should focus on improving the NRR selectivity at high overpotentials, including inhibition of competitive HER. To deal with this challenge, Bi, Ti, and Sn metals and non-metals with poor HER activity should be considered, or the hydrophobic performance of electrodes should be changed for NRR. 3.5 CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) CO2 utilization is a valuable complement to mitigate the greenhouse effect and provide renewable energy and chemicals [156,157]. Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is a very complex process involving multiproton-coupled electron transfer, which results in various valuable products such as CO, CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH, C2H4, C2H5OH, C3H6, C3H7OH and long-chain products [158–160]. However, concerning thermodynamics, CO2 is extremely stable, and high overpotential is needed for CO2RR. Therefore, CO2RR has to compete with HER in the electrocatalytic process [157]. Many electrocatalysts have been designed for CO2RR, but fabricating cheap, active, and selective catalysts are urgently needed. SACs have been considered as the candidate in heterogeneous catalysis for CO2RR. They could reduce the catalytic cost by utilizing almost all the atoms, provide more active catalytic sites by tuning their geometric and electronic configurations, and contribute to higher selectivity due to the presence of very uniform active centers. After stable carbon-based SACs were fabricated with both noble and non-noble metals as the active center, extensive studies were performed on SACs for CO2RR [161]. Noble-metal-based SACs (Au, Ag, Pd, Pt, Sr, Rh, Y, Sr, etc) have been reported for CO2RR [162–164], and DFT computations for noble metals showed that the initial protonation of CO2 to either carboxyl (*COOH) or formate (*OCHO) requires lower free energy than H* formation (H+ + e-). Therefore, CO2RR is more competitive than HER on those SACs [161]. Non-noble-metal-based SACs (Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Mn, Bi, etc) for CO2RR have been extensively studied [162,165–167]. Zhang et al. reported that a catalyst consisting of single Bi atoms on N-doped carbon networks (Bi SA/NC) with exclusive Bi-N4 active sites by thermal decomposition of a Bi-based MOF and dicyandiamide for CO2RR [168]. For comparison, Bi clusters and Bi nanoparticles on the support (Bi C/NC and Bi NP/NC) were also prepared. The Bi SA/NC catalyst showed the highest intrinsic CO2RR activity for CO conversion, with a high FECO and high TOF at a very low overpotential (Fig. 12 a–d). DFT computations demonstrate that the single-atom Bi-N4 site is the dominating active center simultaneously for CO2 activation and the rapid formation of key intermediate COOH* with a low free energy barrier. Hou et al. dispersed single atomic Ni sites on N-doped carbon nanotubes (Ni/NCTs) and porous bulk carbons (Ni/NC) [169], and the obtained Ni/NCTs exhibited enhanced selectivity and activity with high FECO and TOF. Moreover, it could maintain 98% of its initial activity after a continuous electrocatalysis test for 20 h (Fig. 12e–h). Cu-based electrocatalysts are suitable for CO2RR with not only two-electron transfer products (CO and HCOOH) but also other products (CH4, C2H4, C2H5OH, etc.) [161]. Zheng group demonstrated single-atom Cu substituted CeO2 (Cu-CeO2) to optimize CO2RR to CH4 [170]. DFT computations revealed that Cu single atoms can stabilize up to 3 oxygen vacancies around them on CeO2(100) surface and the atomically dispersed Cu with O vacancies acted as the active site for CO2RR with a relatively high CH4 selectivity. However, the current density of CO2RR is greatly limited by the low mass loading of SACs. Increasing the mass loading of SACs will lead to the problem of atom migration and agglomeration [171]. Therefore, the balance between loading and catalytic performances should be considered in the study of SACs for CO2RR. In addition, synthesis of SACs with uniform active sites and determination of the state of active sites are still challenges for CO2RR. 4 Applications of SACs to electrochemical energy storage systems Besides the above-mentioned typical electrocatalytic reactions, SACs could be adopted in some electrochemical energy storage devices such as fuel cells, metal-O2 batteries, metal-CO2 batteries and metal-S batteries. The state-of-the-art electrocatalytic performances for these storage systems are summarized for single-atom electrocatalysts, and shown in Table S1 (Supporting Information). 4.1 Fuel cells Fuel cells with hydrogen (H2) as the energy resource not only demonstrate the advantages of impressive power density and energy efficiency but also offer the potential in practical applications. For a typical fuel cell, it could be regarded as a “reverse” system of overall water electrolysis [172,173]. In this system, H2 is oxidized at the anode and O2 is reduced at the cathode. However, the sluggish kinetics and pathway selectivity lead to low overall energy efficiency. Although platinum group metal-based catalysts have reached a high level for ORR in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), the precious metal-based electrocatalysts for PEMFCs suffer from high cost and severe scarcity; therefore, it is greatly urgent to enhance the metal utilization and/or develop low-loading noble metal-based and/or even precious metal-free catalysts [174,175]. Previous reports unveiled that Pt-N4 sites in Pt-N-C SACs are highly responsive in alkaline solutions but inactive in acidic electrolytes [176]. Besides, high metal atom loading was also anticipated for the achievement of further improved activity. Recently, Liu et al. have proposed an Ir1-N/C SAC by calcining the ZIF-8 precursor in which Zn atoms were replaced with foreign Ir3+ ions [177]. This SAC contained exclusive Ir-N4 sites with a high Ir loading of 4.5 wt% (Fig. 13 a). Different from the coordination of Ir-C4, Ir-C3N, Ir-C2N2 and Ir-CN3, the exclusively atomic Ir-N4 active sites promote significant improvement, that is, a high E onset and E 1/2 of 0.923 and 0.831 V vs RHE with the H2O2 yield below 1.0% were achieved, respectively. When this SAC was applied to PEMFCs, a peak power density of 870 mW cm−2 under 2 bar H2/O2 was created although it was lower than that of the Pt1-N/C catalyst. Note that Ir1-N/C achieved a high specific power density of 6.44 W mgIr −1, markedly surpassing both the Ir/C composite and Pt1-N/C catalyst (1.15 W mgIr −1 and 3.81 W mgPt −1, respectively). This implies a considerable rational use of precious metals by Ir1-N/C SACs (Fig. 13b-c). In addition, the H2-air PEMFCs with Ir1-N/C SACs as the cathode catalyst showed an open circuit voltage (OCV) of ~ 0.94 V and a maximum power density as high as 0.38 W cm−2 (Fig. 13d). Thus, increasing the density of active sites and rational design of the coordination structures are efficient methods to promote the performance of fuel cells. The inevitable corrosion of the cathodic SACs under acidic conditions, i.e., the demethylation and the breakage of N-C bonds, could markedly decrease the catalytic current during long-term tests. This phenomenon was severe, especially for those based on non-noble metals such as Fe [178,179]. It is therefore extremely challenging to well maintain the structural stability of M−N−C sites in strong acid conditions. In addition, note that the Fenton reaction between Fe2+ and byproduct H2O2 would damage the polymer membrane and thus reduce the stability of the cells [180]. Hence, other non-Fe-based SACs keeping away from Fenton reactions are desired as cathode catalysts. Xie et al. demonstrated a Co-N-C catalyst via the immobilization and fencing of Co-N4 sites in the micropores of ZIF-8 precursors with a ligand exchange procedure with 2-methylimidazole [129]. In this Co-N-C structure, most probably porphyrin-like CoN4C12 moieties acted as the reaction sites and were positioned in carbon pores predominantly, as shown in Fig. 13e. Compared with Fe-N-C SACs prepared via a similar procedure, the Co-N-C catalyst showed considerably improved durability owing to both the weakened demetallation and oxidation by radicals (Fig. 13f-g). Particularly, a stable current output of ~ 22.5 mA cm−2 was realized at 0.90 ViR-free by single-atom Co-N-C structure, and the required potential to achieve the current density of 44.0 mA cm−2 was 0.87 ViR-free. In addition, the PEMFCs achieved peak power densities of up to 0.64 and 0.32 W cm cm−2 with the OCV of ~ 0.9 V under 1.0 bar H2/O2 and H2/air conditions, respectively, revealing that Co-N-C SACs might be the state-of-the-art non-Fe platinum-group metal-free cathode catalyst for fuel cells. Wu and co-workers also uncovered that Mn dopants could efficiently enhance the graphitization of carbon skeletons, i.e., the structural stability, which would be conducive to improved corrosion resistance (Fig. 13h,i) [181]. As the practical operation temperature is generally high, and even reaches 200 °C, which may bring about serious corrosion, especially in acidic environments. Future work is urgently desired on advanced cathode catalysts in harsh conditions. 4.2 Metal-O2 batteries Commercial Li-ion batteries, based on ion-intercalation chemistry, are now approaching their performance limit [182,183]. Other novel energy storage devices with higher energy density are therefore urgently anticipated. In the past years, metal-air batteries, with inexhaustible air or pure O2 as the cathodic feedstock, have attracted more attention due to their much higher theoretical capacity than that of Li-ion batteries. Because of the electrolyte species, they are generally classified as aqueous and non-aqueous counterparts, which severely depend on the activity of metal anodes. For aqueous metal-O2 batteries, the reactions proceed as M ↔ Mn+ + ne− for the anode (M = Zn, Al, Mg, etc.) while O2 + ne− + 2H2O ↔ 4OH− on the cathode. On the other hand, as for non-aqueous counterparts, the conversion on the cathode is xN+ + O2 + ne− ↔ N x O2 (herein × = 1 or 2, and N refers to Li, Na, etc.) [184–188]. Apparently the reduction reaction on cathodes is a crucial part of both aqueous and non-aqueous cells. Thus, high-quality air- and/or O2-breathing cathodes with active catalyst loading are expected to permit the continuous O2 supply as well as rapid O2 reduction. Fortunately, for aqueous metal-O2 batteries, the accumulated experience in the design and preparation of alkaline ORR catalysts can be readily transplanted. While for rechargeable aqueous metal-O2 batteries, bifunctional oxygen catalysts with high performance in both OER and ORR are desired. Han et al. proposed a Fe-N x -C SAC by the calcination of Fe-phenanthroline complex precursor (Fig. 14 a). With this SAC as a bifunctional catalyst, rechargeable Zn-air batteries showed a peak power density of 96.4 mW cm2, higher than that of commercial Pt/C (82 mW cm−2) and other reported carbon-based materials [189]. The excellent performance created by SACs demonstrates the future development of electrocatalysts for aqueous metal-air cells. However, the cases in aprotic non-aqueous electrolytes differ much because of the absence of H2O. Both the sluggish formation and decomposition of the discharge products, i.e., peroxides M2O2 and/or superoxides MO2, are the decisive factor on the overall efficiency of the cells. Especially, the discharge products easily deposit on the catalyst surface, and the decomposition requires high overpotentials [190–192]. Hence, it is indispensable to develop porous oxygen catalysts suitable for metal-O2 batteries with non-aqueous electrolytes. SACs as a unique type of catalysts also showed impressive performance in metal-O2 batteries. Hu et al. prepared Ru single atoms distributing in porous N-doped carbon substrates (signed as Ru x SAs-NC, wherein × referred to the Ru loading ratio), as shown in Fig. 14b [28]. The CV curves of both Ru0.1 SAs-NC (blue line) and Ru0.3 SAs-NC (red trace) exhibit higher ORR onset potentials than Ru nanoparticles/N-doped carbon composites (denoted as Ru NPs-NC). While in the anodic sweep, the anodic peaks ascribed to two SACs are much lower, implying the lower overpotential to trigger the decomposition of discharge products, verifying that Ru single atoms on NC substrates markedly promoted Li-O2 chemistry. The responses at ~ 3.70 and ~ 3.18 V result from the reaction of Li2O2 ↔ O2 + 2Li+ + 2e− and LiO2 ↔ O2 + Li+ + e-, respectively, and that at 2.55 V corresponds to ORR (O2 + 2e− + 2Li+ → Li2O2) catalyzed by Ru0.3 SAs-NC. Because of the improved kinetics, the batteries with the cathode loading of SACs displayed higher specific capacity even at different current densities (Fig. 14c). Moreover, the discharge product catalyzed by Ru0.3 SAs-NC turned to possess flower-like homogenous nanostructures while that for pyrolyzed ZIF-8 was solid at the micron level. The nanosized flowers with rich edges implied more accessible oxidation of Li2O2, i.e., lower overpotential was required (Fig. 14d and e). Additionally, SACs were also applied to Na-O2 batteries. As shown in Fig. 14f-i, Lee group proposed to stabilize abundant Fe single atoms via a selective microwave annealing strategy on carbon nanotubes with the co-loading of Fe phthalocyanine (FePc) and melamine [193]. When the SAC, denoted as MA-Fe-N/CNT, was applied as the air cathode for Na-O2 batteries, it exhibited comparable performance to the commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst. The excellent performance revealed the great potential of noble metal-free SACs in Na-O2 batteries. Furthermore, given the huge market of wearable electronic devices, flexible and safe metal-air batteries with solid-state electrolytes are desired. To achieve the high energy density, Chen et al. prepared a SAC (labeled as Fe-N-C) and used it in a flexible all-solid-state Zn-air battery (Fig. 14j) [194]. The Fe-N-C catalyst-employed battery exhibited an output circuit voltage of 1.424 V, which was only 25 mV lower than that adopting the state-of-the-art Pt/C composite (Fig. 14k-l). Notably, the SAC-based battery showed an impressive capacity. However, the high overpotential, low rate capability, and poor cycling performance make it challenging for practical applications, and exploring porous SACs and further accelerating the kinetics/transport process will make significant progress for metal-O2 batteries. Besides M−N−C SACs, some non-carbon-based SACs have also been applied to metal-O2 batteries, showing considerable performance. As shown in Fig. 14m-n, when Co atoms were atomically dispersed on Co3O4 crystallines of Co3O4/N-doped active carbon composites, the as-obtained SAC, denoted as Co-Co3O4/NC, achieved the initial discharge/charge voltage gap of 0.791 V for rechargeable solid-state Zn-air batteries. The gap steadily increased to 0.935 V after long-term cycling of 35 h at 10 mA cm−2, markedly surpassing those from 1.036 V to 2.075 V and 0.901 V to 1.042 V for commercial Pt/C and IrO2-Pt/C. Compared with N-doped carbon materials, these non-carbon substrates themselves show outstanding performance in the reactions including but not limited to electrocatalysis, and thus offer great potential in developing non-carbon-based SACs for more catalytic reaction fields [195]. 4.3 Metal-CO2 batteries Metal-CO2 batteries, with CO2 as the cathode active species, are capable of not only serving as high-efficiency energy systems but also dealing with anthropogenic CO2 emissions to realize benign carbon cycling [196,197]. Similar to metal-O2 batteries, they can also be categorized as non-aqueous and aqueous counterparts according to the electrolyte. For the former, such as rechargeable Li-CO2 batteries, the total reaction with the typical discharge products of Li2CO3 and C can be described as 4Li + 3CO2 ↔ 2Li2CO3 + C [198,199]. For the accommodation of the Li2CO3 product, an air cathode with a large surface area is desired. On the other hand, for the decomposition of Li2CO3, a large voltage is often needed during the charging process because of the intrinsically insulating property of Li2CO3, which may not only cause much energy loss but also result in the degradation of electrolytes [200]. Ground-breaking catalysts are therefore required to promote the sluggish electrochemical processes. In recent years, SACs have proven great adaptability to deal with kinetics issues. For instance, Dai group applied Fe single atom-implanted holey N,S co-doped graphene (denoted as Fe-ISA/N,S-HG) to non-aqueous Li-CO2 batteries (Fig. 15 a and b) [201]. The full discharge/charge profiles in Fig. 15c depicted that Fe-ISA/N,S-HG delivered specific discharge and charge capacity of 23.174 and 21.520 Ah g−1, respectively, significantly surpassing the calcined holey graphene oxide at 900 °C (signed as HGO-900) and single-atom Fe implanted N,S co-doped graphene without holes (labeled as Fe-ISA/N,S-G). The initial discharge/charge profiles tested under the limited discharge/charge capacity of 1.0 Ah g−1, as depicted in Fig. 15d, show that Fe-ISA/N,S-HG possessed both the lowest charge voltage and the highest discharge voltage among these catalysts, i.e., the best bifunctional activity in catalyzing both the formation and decomposition of discharge product Li2CO3. After discharge, ultrafine Li2CO3 nanoparticles with a diameter of 2–10 nm formed on Fe-ISA/N,S-HG electrode, differing from those with the size over 50 nm on previously reported catalysts. Such small nanoparticles were easily decomposed and thus resulted in favorable charge kinetics (Fig. 15e-f). In addition, Zhang et al. proposed a novel structure of adjacent Co single atom-loaded graphene oxide (denoted as adjacent Co/GO) for aprotic Li-CO2 chemistry. Unexpectedly, as a result of the synergetic interaction of Co-Co and Co-O configurations, the unique adjacent Co/GO catalyst showed higher activity in the decomposition of Li2CO3 than both single-atom Co-anchored graphene oxide and Co cluster/graphene oxide composites, offering guidance for the rational design of SACs by coordination optimization [202]. While for aqueous metal-CO2 batteries, such as Zn-CO2 batteries, variable proton-coupled electron transfer pathways are allowed to implement flexible CO2 electrochemistry [198]. During the discharge, value-added fuels/chemicals, such as CO and HCOOH, may be produced, realizing valuable C recycles. In other words, the practical conversion is rather complicated and the products severely depend on the electrocatalysts. Traditional precious metal catalysts, such as Pd and Au, have shown great potential for CO2 reduction [203,204]. However, they have high costs, and generally need high overpotentials to yield desired products. Also, the FE, such as for CO2-to-CO conversion in Zn-CO2 batteries, is below 50%, especially at relatively high discharge currents. As an alternative, SACs, especially those containing nitrogen-coordinated transition metal configurations, are greatly cherished. Recently, Ni et al. have demonstrated a catalyst of single-atom Fe anchored on defect-rich N-doped graphene (simplified as SAFe/DNG) for the cathode of Zn-CO2 batteries (Fig. 15g-n) [205]. A maximum energy density of 4.33 Wh cm−2 was achieved at the current density of 4.3 mA cm−2 by this defect-rich SAC. Moreover, the FE for yielding CO reached the peak value of 86.5% at 5.0 mA cm−2 and remained over 80% at the current density up to 7.0 mA cm−2. Such high performance was far superior to that of many advanced electrocatalysts [206,207]. 4.4 Metal-S batteries Metal-S batteries adopting high-capacity metallic Li anodes and low-cost sulfur cathodes, have been demonstrated to deliver high energy density, and are regarded as another promising candidate for next-generation batteries [208]. As an example, for Li-S batteries, the discharge process proceeds by the mechanism: 16Li + S8 → 8Li2S, in which complicated solid–liquid-solid conversion occurs (Fig. 16 a) [209]. Due to the high solubility of long-chain polysulfide intermediates (such as Li2S6), a serious shuttling effect generally emerges and thus leads to the increase of internal resistance, low S utilization, and rapid capacity decay along with continuous cycling, as depicted in Fig. 16b [210]. Moreover, S powder as well discharge products (such as Li2S2 and Li2S) are inherently insulating, giving rise to the sluggish reaction kinetics of Li-S chemistry. While on Li anodes, various components (soluble polysulfides in particular) in the electrolyte would induce repeated Li plating and stripping. Such behavior easily causes non-uniform Li deposition, i.e., the formation of unwanted lithium dendrites, resulting in early failure and safety issues. By a feat of the physical confinement with carbonaceous materials, polysulfides could be efficiently wrapped up and/or blocked [211]. In particular, the chemical interaction between polysulfides and heteroatom dopants in a substrate (such as carbon materials) was verified as a valid way to markedly alleviate shuttling effects and enhance S utilization (Fig. 16c). In other words, rationally developing SACs as catalysts would be a promising strategy to modulate the performance of Li-S batteries by promoting the interconversion of sulfur species, efficient trapping of polysulfides, and regular Li nucleation/growth. Very recently, Zhou et al. have investigated the Li-S chemistry of various single atom-anchored N-doped graphene catalysts (denoted as SAM@NG, M = Fe, Mn, Ru, Zn, Co or V), as depicted in Fig. 16d [210]. Both the bare graphene and N-doped graphene (labeled as NG) possess higher Li2S decomposition barriers than the SAM@NG catalysts. While the Li+ diffusion barriers for all the graphene materials with or without single-atom loading are almost the same (~0.23 eV). In addition, the binding between Li2S6 and the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 16e, implied that SAV@NG might show the best promise in eliminating the dissolution of polysulfides and thus suppressing the adverse shuttling effect. Combining these results, it could be concluded that SAM@NG, especially SAV@NG, might be an optimal catalyst. Stimulated by this point, they further applied these catalysts to the practical cathode of Li-S batteries (Fig. 16f–i). The decreased concentration of Li2S6 in the solution with SAV@NG additive confirmed the best adsorption ability on S6 2-. Moreover, the charge/discharge plateau gap was the lowest for SAV@NG, suggesting the best reaction kinetics and highest reversibility. Besides, the SAV@NG electrode displayed the largest current response among the catalysts under identical conditions, revealing the rapid redox conversion of sulfur species on the catalyst surface. Also, the Gibbs energy change confirmed the favorable Li-S chemistry for SAV@NG. The above-mentioned adsorption and simultaneous catalytic strategy were intensively tried for SACs, especially those with conventional carbon substrates. The discharge end-product, Li2S, is solid and overspreads on SACs easily, preventing the tight contact between the catalysts and polysulfides, and thus giving rise to catalyst deactivation. Shi et al. proposed adding a highly soluble SAC, cobalt hexadecachlorophthalocyanine (CoPcCl), into the electrolyte to construct a solid/liquid interface between the catalyst and solid products [212]. Promoted dynamics were evidenced by the augmented current response (Fig. 16j, wherein STD is referred to as the standard electrolyte). This example may provide another promising strategy for high-performance Li-S batteries. Apart from Li-S batteries, SACs are also used in Na-S chemistry. Compared with those for Li-S chemistry, the above-mentioned issues are more severe for Na-S batteries. For instance, it is even difficult to realize the entire conversion between solid Na2S2 and Na2S due to the deficient conductivity, affecting the overall performance of Na-S batteries [213]. In this regard, Islam group conducted computations on the decomposition barrier of bare Na2S and Na2S on single-atom transition metal-anchored N-doped graphene substrates (denoted as Na2S-M/NG, M = Cr, Fe and/or Co) [214]. The results in Fig. 16l show that the SACs could substantially reduce the decomposition barrier and the catalytic conversion barrier varied with the anchoring metal species. Besides, Lai et al. also investigated the Na-S chemistry of single-atom Fe or Pt on nitrogen-doped carbon fibers (signed as Fe1@NC and Pt1@NC, respectively) [215]. Fig. 16m shows that the binding energy increases from long-chain polysulfides to short-chain counterparts for Fe1@NC, while Pt1@NC possesses weak adsorption on short-chain polysulfides and strong binding properties on long-chain counterparts. The results revealed that the discharge products catalyzed by Pt1@NC were mainly long-chain polysulfides while S could be directly transformed into short-chain Na2S easily, which could also be evidenced by the in-situ XRD patterns (Fig. 16n-o). Developing other SACs with various metal centers and higher loading is expected to further promote metal-S batteries. 5 Conclusion and perspectives The development and application of SACs are highly promising in the fields of electrochemical energy storage and conversion. In this review, we summarize the commonly used fabrication processes for SACs in five categories: coprecipitation, wetness impregnation, low-temperature chemical reduction, atomic‐layer deposition, and high-temperature pyrolysis. The practical applications of SACs to typical electrocatalytic reactions (HER, OER, ORR, NRR, and CO2RR) and energy storage devices (fuel cells, metal-O2 batteries, metal-CO2 batteries, and metal-S batteries) are also illustrated with high selectivity and electrochemical activity. For each reaction, we discussed the electrocatalytic activity for SACs. Especially, the definitive coordination structure of SACs makes it possible to illustrate the electron distribution and further understand the mechanisms of electrochemical processes. Although these fabrication processes and practical applications were approached for the SACs with different loadings, the challenges remain in the controllable fabrication and application in electrocatalysis of SACs with massive single atoms on the supports. The controllable and efficient synthesis should be developed to satisfy the practical requirement. The universal problems for the SAC synthesis focus on low active metal loading, which restricts practical applications. However, increasing the electrocatalytic efficiency by enhancing metal loading is challenging because high surface energy makes SACs chemically unstable and single atoms tend to aggregate into clusters or nanoparticles. Recently, various SACs have been also fabricated via high-temperature or other energy-intensive processes. However, for common metal oxide supports, high temperature would promote the formation of metal clusters rather than single atoms. Therefore, facile synthesis strategies should be further exploited to maintain good dispersion of SACs with high activity and massive production for practical applications. The stability of SACs is vital for practical applications. In the electrocatalytic processes, SACs will aggregate or dissolute in acidic or basic media due to high surface free energies and low-coordination numbers of single metal atoms, resulting in significant activity loss. Although many strategies have been developed to address the stability issues, the loading of metal atoms is still lower than 1.5 wt%. Therefore, suitable supports with numerous anchor sites provide a selectable pathway to fabricating SACs. In addition, the appropriate interaction of SACs and the supports is significant to stabilize SACs and prevent aggregation but not to sacrifice much activity. Advanced characterization technologies, especially in-situ or operando technologies, such as XRD, TEM, STEM, XAFS and Raman spectroscopy, are admirable to understand the mechanisms for electrochemical processes and the relationship between the structure and the performances at the atomic level. However, the important characterization technology, especially XAFS, is very rare at present. The in situ or operando tests are time-consuming. Although the development of characterization technologies has provided evidence for SACs, the reaction pathway of electrocatalytic processes is unclear due to the lack of characterization technologies. Furthermore, it is necessary to develop effective computational methods to screen and design SACs and investigate the mechanisms under real experimental conditions [216]. coredata.dc:description: The expedited consumption of fossil fuels has triggered broad interest in the fabrication of novel catalysts for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Especially, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted more attention owing to their high specific surface areas and abundant active centers. This review summarizes recent synthetic strategies to fabricate SACs with different metal loadings on various supports, and the structural influence of supports on metal loading. Then, the functions of SACs are illustrated on electronic structure and electrocatalysis; the isolated SACs with an unsaturated coordination environment generally accelerate the electrocatalytic process and promote the selectivity. The applications of SACs to some typical electrocatalytic reactions are also introduced in detail, as well as to electrochemical energy storage and conversion systems. Finally, the challenges and the perspectives of SACs are discussed for future exploration.
